sect2.para: Studies on transcultural transcultural differences show that reporting persistent somatic symptoms and associated distress is a common phenomenon worldwide (e. g., Üstun & Sartorius, 1995 ). One huge problem is that studies examining transcultural differences in SSRD and somatic symptom report use scales that have mainly been developed in Western countries and are not sensitive toward culturally specific symptoms. Somatic symptoms are, however, prominent in so-called “ cultural concepts of distress ,” defined as “ways that cultural groups experience experience , understand, and communicate suffering, behavioral problems, or troubling thoughts and emotions” (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 , p. 871). An example is Ataque de nervios, a syndrome in individuals of Latin descent, which includes intense emotional upset and various somatic symptoms such as trembling, heat in the chest, or seizure-like episodes. The DSM-5-TR provides a glossary of nine cultural concepts of distress. We strongly recommend to additionally apply the Cultural Formulation Interview (American Psychiatric Association, 2022 ) in a diagnostic process to assess SSDR in individuals with a cultural background different different from the interviewers’ cultural background.

sect2.title: Socioeconomic Status and Level of Education
sect2.para: The results results on relationships between somatoform disorders and socioeconomic status and level of education are mixed. A high-quality epidemiological study conducted in Germany demonstrated that the highest prevalence rates of somatoform disorders occurred in individuals of the lowest socioeconomic level and those who are unemployed, divorced, widowed, or live in separation (Jacobi et al., 2004 ). There are no differences between patients with IAD and the general population in terms of socioeconomic status and level of education (Scarella et al., 2019 ).
